dialogue: It failed because the House did not pass it and the House failed by eleven votes.
snippet_sentences: ["We were threatened by a veto if we passed a dollar and a quarter - it's extremely difficult with the great power that the president does to pass any bill when the president is opposed to it."]
snippet: We were threatened by a veto if we passed a dollar and a quarter - it's extremely difficult with the great power that the president does to pass any bill when the president is opposed to it.

dialogue_sentences: ['All the president needs to sustain his veto of any bill is one-third plus one in either the House or the Senate.', 'Secondly, we passed a federal aid to education bill in the Senate.', 'It failed to came to the floor of the House of Representatives.']
dialogue: All the president needs to sustain his veto of any bill is one-third plus one in either the House or the Senate. Secondly, we passed a federal aid to education bill in the Senate. It failed to came to the floor of the House of Representatives.
snippet_sentences: ['It was killed in the Rules Committee.']
snippet: It was killed in the Rules Committee.

dialogue_sentences: ['When the president exercises his veto power, he has to have the people upo- behind him, not just a third of the Congress.', "Because let's consider it.", "If the majority of the members of the Congress felt that these particular proposals were good issues - the majority of those who were Democrats - why didn't they pass them and send to the President and get a veto and have an issue?"]
dialogue: When the president exercises his veto power, he has to have the people upo- behind him, not just a third of the Congress. Because let's consider it. If the majority of the members of the Congress felt that these particular proposals were good issues - the majority of those who were Democrats - why didn't they pass them and send to the President and get a veto and have an issue?
snippet_sentences: ['The reason why these particular bills in these various fields that have been mentioned were not passed was not because the President was against them; it was because the people were against them.']
snippet: The reason why these particular bills in these various fields that have been mentioned were not passed was not because the President was against them; it was because the people were against them.

dialogue_sentences: ['Whenever a majority of the people are for a program, the House and the Senate responds to it.', 'And whether this House and Senate, in the next session is Democratic or Republican, if the country will have voted for the candidate for the presidency and for the proposals that he has made, I believe that you will find that the president, if it were a Republican, as it would be in my case, would be able to get his program through that Congress.', "Now, I also say that as far as Senator Kennedy's proposals are concerned, that, again, the question is not simply one of uh - a presidential veto stopping programs."]
dialogue: Whenever a majority of the people are for a program, the House and the Senate responds to it. And whether this House and Senate, in the next session is Democratic or Republican, if the country will have voted for the candidate for the presidency and for the proposals that he has made, I believe that you will find that the president, if it were a Republican, as it would be in my case, would be able to get his program through that Congress. Now, I also say that as far as Senator Kennedy's proposals are concerned, that, again, the question is not simply one of uh - a presidential veto stopping programs.
snippet_sentences: ["You must always remember that a president can't stop anything unless he has the people behind him."]
snippet: You must always remember that a president can't stop anything unless he has the people behind him.

dialogue_sentences: ['And whether this House and Senate, in the next session is Democratic or Republican, if the country will have voted for the candidate for the presidency and for the proposals that he has made, I believe that you will find that the president, if it were a Republican, as it would be in my case, would be able to get his program through that Congress.', "Now, I also say that as far as Senator Kennedy's proposals are concerned, that, again, the question is not simply one of uh - a presidential veto stopping programs.", "You must always remember that a president can't stop anything unless he has the people behind him."]
dialogue: And whether this House and Senate, in the next session is Democratic or Republican, if the country will have voted for the candidate for the presidency and for the proposals that he has made, I believe that you will find that the president, if it were a Republican, as it would be in my case, would be able to get his program through that Congress. Now, I also say that as far as Senator Kennedy's proposals are concerned, that, again, the question is not simply one of uh - a presidential veto stopping programs. You must always remember that a president can't stop anything unless he has the people behind him.
snippet_sentences: ["And the reason President Eisenhower's vetoes have been sustained - the reason the Congress does not send up bills to him which they think will be vetoed - is because the people and the Congress, the majority of them, know the country is behind the President."]
snippet: And the reason President Eisenhower's vetoes have been sustained - the reason the Congress does not send up bills to him which they think will be vetoed - is because the people and the Congress, the majority of them, know the country is behind the President.

dialogue_sentences: ['Have to do it.', "I'd like the government to have that.", 'And I think it would discipline not only the Congress, which needs it, but also the executive branch.']
dialogue: Have to do it. I'd like the government to have that. And I think it would discipline not only the Congress, which needs it, but also the executive branch.
snippet_sentences: ["I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto, so if the Congress can't cut, and we've got a reckless spending Congress, let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature."]
snippet: I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto, so if the Congress can't cut, and we've got a reckless spending Congress, let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature.

dialogue_sentences: ["I'll tell you exactly what I think can be done.", 'I think we can bring it down by 50% in 4 years and grow the economy.', 'So my view is, sir, you have to increase investment, grow the economy and reduce the deficit by controlling health care costs, prudent reductions in defense, cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.']
dialogue: I'll tell you exactly what I think can be done. I think we can bring it down by 50% in 4 years and grow the economy. So my view is, sir, you have to increase investment, grow the economy and reduce the deficit by controlling health care costs, prudent reductions in defense, cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.
snippet_sentences: ["I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people, including a lot of Republicans said, this is the way you've got to go."]
snippet: I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people, including a lot of Republicans said, this is the way you've got to go.

dialogue_sentences: ["We'll pass on the American dream to our children, and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today.", 'When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living.', 'Today it will take 12 generations.']
dialogue: We'll pass on the American dream to our children, and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today. When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living. Today it will take 12 generations.
snippet_sentences: ['Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.']
snippet: Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.

dialogue_sentences: ["As you all know, I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues.", "And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one.", "We'll be on again Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC."]
dialogue: As you all know, I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues. And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one. We'll be on again Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC.
snippet_sentences: ["-- I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more."]
snippet: -- I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more.

dialogue_sentences: ["And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one.", "We'll be on again Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC.", "-- I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more."]
dialogue: And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one. We'll be on again Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC. -- I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more.
snippet_sentences: ["And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling, let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs, health care, crime, the things that concern the American people."]
snippet: And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling, let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs, health care, crime, the things that concern the American people.

dialogue_sentences: ['And everything in there says what I am for.', "Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal, a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy.", "My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years, so I feel I've been talking issues."]
dialogue: And everything in there says what I am for. Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal, a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy. My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years, so I feel I've been talking issues.
snippet_sentences: ["You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it."]
snippet: You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it.

dialogue_sentences: ['I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy, and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor, duty and country man; and he said tell the truth.', "And I've tried to do that in public life, all through it.", 'That says something about character.']
dialogue: I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy, and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor, duty and country man; and he said tell the truth. And I've tried to do that in public life, all through it. That says something about character.
snippet_sentences: ["My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling, but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war."]
snippet: My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling, but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war.

dialogue_sentences: ['How would he feel about it?', "But maybe that's generational.", "I don't know."]
dialogue: How would he feel about it? But maybe that's generational. I don't know.
snippet_sentences: ["But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling.", "And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House."]
snippet: But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling. And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House.

dialogue_sentences: ["And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House.", 'I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers.', 'I also had a program starting last year.']
dialogue: And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House. I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers. I also had a program starting last year.
snippet_sentences: ["I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign."]
snippet: I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign.

dialogue_sentences: ["He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives.", "So I'm not going to take up your time tonight, but let me just say this.", "We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again."]
dialogue: He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives. So I'm not going to take up your time tonight, but let me just say this. We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again.
snippet_sentences: ['But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn\'t believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote "political chameleon" for changing his positions of all times.']
snippet: But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote "political chameleon" for changing his positions of all times.

dialogue_sentences: ["Here's my point.", "I'm not interested in his character.", 'I want to change the character of the presidency.']
dialogue: Here's my point. I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the presidency.
snippet_sentences: ["And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years.", "So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you."]
snippet: And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years. So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.

dialogue_sentences: ["So in principle, though, I'll take your point and think we ought to discuss child care or whatever else it is.", 'Ross had his hand up.', 'Just no hedges, no ifs, ands and buts.']
dialogue: So in principle, though, I'll take your point and think we ought to discuss child care or whatever else it is. Ross had his hand up. Just no hedges, no ifs, ands and buts.
snippet_sentences: ["I'll take the pledge because I know the American people want to talk about issues and not tabloid journalism."]
snippet: I'll take the pledge because I know the American people want to talk about issues and not tabloid journalism.

dialogue_sentences: ["I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this, because there's been a lot of hue and cry.", 'We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure.', 'That happened when I was president.']
dialogue: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this, because there's been a lot of hue and cry. We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president.
snippet_sentences: ["And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very, very good beginning."]
snippet: And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very, very good beginning.

dialogue_sentences: ['We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure.', 'That happened when I was president.', "And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very, very good beginning."]
dialogue: We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure. That happened when I was president. And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very, very good beginning.
snippet_sentences: ["Like Mr. Perot, I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money, but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down."]
snippet: Like Mr. Perot, I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money, but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down.

dialogue_sentences: ['They can do better.', 'Everyone knows that.', "But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about."]
dialogue: They can do better. Everyone knows that. But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about.
snippet_sentences: ['Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.']
snippet: Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.

dialogue_sentences: ['If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork.', 'That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.', "And that's why he wants to veto it, just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year."]
dialogue: If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork. That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it, just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year.
snippet_sentences: ['This is not mud slinging.', 'This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year.']
snippet: This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year.

dialogue_sentences: ['Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing.', 'I agree with him.', 'I mean, we agree with that.']
dialogue: Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean, we agree with that.
snippet_sentences: ['And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs.', 'There are 200,000 people in California, for example, who have lost their defense related jobs.']
snippet: And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs. There are 200,000 people in California, for example, who have lost their defense related jobs.

dialogue_sentences: ["The president wants it, but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year.", "We didn't fund a lot of other things this year, like the savings and loan mess.", "That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election."]
dialogue: The president wants it, but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year. We didn't fund a lot of other things this year, like the savings and loan mess. That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.
snippet_sentences: ['The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting.', 'These people are hurting in the inner cities.']
snippet: The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting. These people are hurting in the inner cities.

dialogue_sentences: ['Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.', 'Our enterprise zones, that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress, would bring jobs into the inner city.', "There's a good program."]
dialogue: Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements. Our enterprise zones, that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress, would bring jobs into the inner city. There's a good program.
snippet_sentences: ['And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.']
snippet: And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.

dialogue_sentences: ['This is not mud slinging.', 'This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year.', 'But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.']
dialogue: This is not mud slinging. This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year. But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.
snippet_sentences: ['Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing.', 'I agree with him.', 'I mean, we agree with that.']
snippet: Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing. I agree with him. I mean, we agree with that.

dialogue_sentences: ["First you've got to have money to pay for these things.", "So you've got to create jobs.", 'There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city.']
dialogue: First you've got to have money to pay for these things. So you've got to create jobs. There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city.
snippet_sentences: ["I'm not a politician, but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it.", 'I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it.']
snippet: I'm not a politician, but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it. I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it.

dialogue_sentences: ['Sure, but the problem is, you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good.', "That's the problem with our system.", 'If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork.']
dialogue: Sure, but the problem is, you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good. That's the problem with our system. If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork.
snippet_sentences: ['That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.', "And that's why he wants to veto it, just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year."]
snippet: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more. And that's why he wants to veto it, just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year.

dialogue_sentences: ['I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill.', 'We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.', "The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control, but it's very important -- we need more police on the street."]
dialogue: I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill. We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up. The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control, but it's very important -- we need more police on the street.
snippet_sentences: ["There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street, which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate, mostly be Republican senators, and I think it's a shame it didn't pass, I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it, the waiting period."]
snippet: There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street, which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate, mostly be Republican senators, and I think it's a shame it didn't pass, I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it, the waiting period.

dialogue_sentences: ["Brady Bill, I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it.", "So why pass a law that won't fix it?", "Now, what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent."]
dialogue: Brady Bill, I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it. So why pass a law that won't fix it? Now, what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent.
snippet_sentences: ["And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately."]
snippet: And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately.

dialogue_sentences: ['Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it.', 'And at that point, we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans.', "And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another, put together the best program, take it to the American people, use the electronic town hall, the kind of thing you're doing here tonight, build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one."]
dialogue: Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it. And at that point, we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans. And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another, put together the best program, take it to the American people, use the electronic town hall, the kind of thing you're doing here tonight, build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one.
snippet_sentences: ["But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing."]
snippet: But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.

dialogue_sentences: ['Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime.', "I am for the right, as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons.", 'But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.']
dialogue: Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime. I am for the right, as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons. But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.
snippet_sentences: ["I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock, Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation."]
snippet: I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock, Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation.

dialogue_sentences: ["And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately.", "That's where we are.", 'We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require.']
dialogue: And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately. That's where we are. We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require.
snippet_sentences: ['Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it.']
snippet: Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it.

dialogue_sentences: ["I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.", "Virginia's in the lead in this, as Governor Clinton properly said, on this identification system for firearms.", 'I am not for national registration of firearms.']
dialogue: I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers. Virginia's in the lead in this, as Governor Clinton properly said, on this identification system for firearms. I am not for national registration of firearms.
snippet_sentences: ['Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime.']
snippet: Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime.

dialogue_sentences: ["The president's terms are limited to 2, a total of 8 years.", "What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12?", 'Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.']
dialogue: The president's terms are limited to 2, a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.
snippet_sentences: ["For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together."]
snippet: For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.

dialogue_sentences: ["For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.", "We've got to do something about it.", 'And I think you get a certain arrogance, bureaucratic arrogance, if people stay there too long.']
dialogue: For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together. We've got to do something about it. And I think you get a certain arrogance, bureaucratic arrogance, if people stay there too long.
snippet_sentences: ['And so I favor, strongly favor, term limits.']
snippet: And so I favor, strongly favor, term limits.

dialogue_sentences: ['So we need to do the reforms and the term limits.', "And after we reform it, it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30,000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.", "They're all nice people, they're just in a bad system."]
dialogue: So we need to do the reforms and the term limits. And after we reform it, it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30,000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign. They're all nice people, they're just in a bad system.
snippet_sentences: ["I don't think there are any villains, but, boy, is the system rotten."]
snippet: I don't think there are any villains, but, boy, is the system rotten.

dialogue_sentences: ['And how to get them passed?', 'Send us some people that will pass the idea.', 'And I think you will.']
dialogue: And how to get them passed? Send us some people that will pass the idea. And I think you will.

dialogue_sentences: ["The president's terms are limited to 2, a total of 8 years.", "What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12?", 'Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.']
dialogue: The president's terms are limited to 2, a total of 8 years. What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12? Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.
snippet_sentences: ["For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together."]
snippet: For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.

dialogue_sentences: ['Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.', "For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.", "We've got to do something about it."]

snippet_sentences: ['And I think you get a certain arrogance, bureaucratic arrogance, if people stay there too long.']
snippet: And I think you get a certain arrogance, bureaucratic arrogance, if people stay there too long.

dialogue_sentences: ["You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.", 'Now, let me tell you what I favor instead.', "I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress, strict limits on political action committees, requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now."]
dialogue: You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress. Now, let me tell you what I favor instead. I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress, strict limits on political action committees, requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now.
snippet_sentences: ["If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races, and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight."]
snippet: If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races, and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.

dialogue_sentences: ["And I think that's the only answer.", 'But the more immediate answer is to do what this lady was suggesting we do, and that is to get this deficit down and get on without adding to the woes, and then restructure.', "One thing I've called for that has been stymied, and I'll keep on working for it, is a whole financial reform legislation."]
dialogue: And I think that's the only answer. But the more immediate answer is to do what this lady was suggesting we do, and that is to get this deficit down and get on without adding to the woes, and then restructure. One thing I've called for that has been stymied, and I'll keep on working for it, is a whole financial reform legislation.

dialogue_sentences: ["Let's make sure this thing's as good as we all think it is at the end of the meeting.", 'Then finally, our government passes laws and freezes the plan in concrete.', "Anybody that's ever built a successful business will tell you you optimize, optimize, optimize after you've put something into effect."]

snippet: The reason Medicare and Medicaid are a mess is we froze them.

dialogue_sentences: ["If it hadn't been for us, Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons.", 'Excuse me, Carole.', "Well, it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War."]

snippet_sentences: ['Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one, and worse.']

dialogue_sentences: ["Well, first, Jim, let me thank you and thank you, Senator Dole, and thank you, ladies and gentlemen, all of you listening tonight for the chance you've given us to appear.", 'I want to say in the beginning that I am profoundly grateful for the chance that you have given me to serve as president for the last four years.', "I never could have dreamed anything like this would come my way in life, and I've done my best to be faithful to the charge you've given me."]
dialogue: Well, first, Jim, let me thank you and thank you, Senator Dole, and thank you, ladies and gentlemen, all of you listening tonight for the chance you've given us to appear. I want to say in the beginning that I am profoundly grateful for the chance that you have given me to serve as president for the last four years. I never could have dreamed anything like this would come my way in life, and I've done my best to be faithful to the charge you've given me.
snippet_sentences: ["I'm proud of the fact that America is stronger and more prosperous and more secure than we were four years ago."]
snippet: I'm proud of the fact that America is stronger and more prosperous and more secure than we were four years ago.

dialogue: The auto worker in Toledo who was unemployed when I was elected and now has a great job because we're number one in auto production again. All the people I've met who used to be on welfare who are now working and raising their children. And I think what others could do for our country and themselves if we did the welfare reform thing in the proper way.

snippet: I think of the man who grabbed me by the shoulder once with tears in his eyes and said his daughter was dying of cancer and he thanked me for giving him a chance to spend some time with her without losing his job because of the Family and Medical Leave Act.

dialogue_sentences: ['And I think what others could do for our country and themselves if we did the welfare reform thing in the proper way.', 'I think of the man who grabbed me by the shoulder once with tears in his eyes and said his daughter was dying of cancer and he thanked me for giving him a chance to spend some time with her without losing his job because of the Family and Medical Leave Act.', 'I think of all the people I grew up with and went to school with and who I stay in touch with and who nerve let me forget how what we do in Washington affects all of you out there in America.']
dialogue: And I think what others could do for our country and themselves if we did the welfare reform thing in the proper way. dialogue_sentences: ['Absolutely not.', "Let's look at the position."]

snippet_sentences: ["First of all, remember that in this campaign season, since Senator Dole's been a candidate, he has bragged about the fact that he voted against Medicare in the beginning, in 1965, one of only 12 members."]
snippet: First of all, remember that in this campaign season, since Senator Dole's been a candidate, he has bragged about the fact that he voted against Medicare in the beginning, in 1965, one of only 12 members.

dialogue_sentences: ["And now with this risky $550 billion tax scheme of Senator Dole's, even his own friends, his campaign co-chair, Senator D'Amato, says that they can't possibly pay for it without cutting Medicare more and cutting Social Security as well, according to him.", 'Now, my balanced budget plan adds ten years to the life of the Medicare trust fund, ten years.', "And we'll have time to deal with the long-term problems of the baby boomers."]
dialogue: And now with this risky $550 billion tax scheme of Senator Dole's, even his own friends, his campaign co-chair, Senator D'Amato, says that they can't possibly pay for it without cutting Medicare more and cutting Social Security as well, according to him. Now, my balanced budget plan adds ten years to the life of the Medicare trust fund, ten years. And we'll have time to deal with the long-term problems of the baby boomers.
snippet_sentences: ['But it was simply wrong to finance their last scheme to cut Medicare $270 billion to run the risk of it withering on the vine.']
snippet: But it was simply wrong to finance their last scheme to cut Medicare $270 billion to run the risk of it withering on the vine.

dialogue_sentences: ['We ought to appoint a commission, just as we did in Social Security in 1983, when we rescued Social Security, and I was proud to be on that commission, along with Claude Pepper, the champion of senior citizens from Florida.', 'And we can do it again, if we take politics out of it.', 'Stop scaring the seniors, Mr. President.']
dialogue: We ought to appoint a commission, just as we did in Social Security in 1983, when we rescued Social Security, and I was proud to be on that commission, along with Claude Pepper, the champion of senior citizens from Florida. And we can do it again, if we take politics out of it. Stop scaring the seniors, Mr. President.
snippet_sentences: ["You've already spent $45 million scaring seniors and tearing me apart."]
snippet: You've already spent $45 million scaring seniors and tearing me apart.

dialogue_sentences: ['Well, I must say, I look back at the vote on Medicare in 1965, we had a program called Eldercare that also provided drugs and means tests to people who needed medical attention received it.', 'I thought it was a good program.', "But I've supported Medicare ever since."]
dialogue: Well, I must say, I look back at the vote on Medicare in 1965, we had a program called Eldercare that also provided drugs and means tests to people who needed medical attention received it. I thought it was a good program. But I've supported Medicare ever since.
snippet_sentences: ["In fact, I used to go home, my mother would tell me, Bob, all I've got is my Social Security and my Medicare, don't cut it.", "I wouldn't violate anything my mother said.", 'In fact, we had a conversation about our mothers one day, a very poignant conversation in the White House.', "I'm concerned about healthcare."]
snippet: In fact, I used to go home, my mother would tell me, Bob, all I've got is my Social Security and my Medicare, don't cut it. I wouldn't violate anything my mother said.
