dialogue_sentences: ['I see what it does.', 'Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together.', 'We must not be divided on this issue.']
dialogue: I see what it does. Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue.
snippet_sentences: ['The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues.']
snippet: The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues.

dialogue_sentences: ['Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together.', 'We must not be divided on this issue.', 'The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues.']
dialogue: Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue. The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues.
snippet_sentences: ['I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it, I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience, whoever may be listening, remember, if you believe in America, if you want America to set the right example to the world, that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice.']
snippet: I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it, I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience, whoever may be listening, remember, if you believe in America, if you want America to set the right example to the world, that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice.

dialogue_sentences: ['The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration.', 'We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years, by a great deal.', "And I only want to say that however good the record is, it's got to be better."]
dialogue: The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration. We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years, by a great deal. And I only want to say that however good the record is, it's got to be better.
snippet_sentences: ["Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward, all Americans must move forward together, and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management."]
snippet: Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward, all Americans must move forward together, and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management.

dialogue_sentences: ['He can set up a fact-finding committee.', "The fact-finding committee's powers are limited.", "He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days, then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress."]
dialogue: He can set up a fact-finding committee. The fact-finding committee's powers are limited. He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days, then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress.
snippet_sentences: ['This is a difficult and sensitive matter.']
snippet: This is a difficult and sensitive matter.

dialogue_sentences: ['He has taken the position, when he first indicated in October of last year, that he would even favor compulsory arbitration as one of the weapons the president might have to stop a national emergency strike.', 'I understand in his last speech before the Steelworkers Union, that he changed that position and indicated that he felt that government seizure might be the best way to stop a strike which could not be settled by collective bargaining.', 'I do not believe we should have either compulsory arbitration or seizure.']
dialogue: He has taken the position, when he first indicated in October of last year, that he would even favor compulsory arbitration as one of the weapons the president might have to stop a national emergency strike. I understand in his last speech before the Steelworkers Union, that he changed that position and indicated that he felt that government seizure might be the best way to stop a strike which could not be settled by collective bargaining. I do not believe we should have either compulsory arbitration or seizure.
snippet_sentences: ['I think the moment that you give to the union, on the one side, and to management, on the other side, the escape hatch of eventually going to government to get it settled, that most of these great strikes will end up being settled by government, and that will be a - be in the end, in my opinion, wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want.']
snippet: I think the moment that you give to the union, on the one side, and to management, on the other side, the escape hatch of eventually going to government to get it settled, that most of these great strikes will end up being settled by government, and that will be a - be in the end, in my opinion, wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want.

dialogue_sentences: ['Yes, I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress.', 'The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense, which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War.']
dialogue: Yes, I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense, which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War.
snippet_sentences: ["On the question of the cost of our budget, I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half, possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program."]
snippet: On the question of the cost of our budget, I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half, possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program.

dialogue_sentences: ['I would hope, under a different monetary policy, that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden, at least a billion dollars.', "Third, I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding, on expense accounts.", "Fourthly, I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care, doctors' bills, nurses, hospitals, when they retire."]
dialogue: I would hope, under a different monetary policy, that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden, at least a billion dollars. Third, I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding, on expense accounts. Fourthly, I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care, doctors' bills, nurses, hospitals, when they retire.
snippet_sentences: ['It is actuarially sound.']
snippet: It is actuarially sound.

dialogue_sentences: ["Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way.", "Well, what he is saying there in effect, we're going to have inflation.", "We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board."]
dialogue: Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well, what he is saying there in effect, we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board.
snippet_sentences: ["I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation, through a phony interest rate."]
snippet: I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation, through a phony interest rate.

dialogue_sentences: ['It is actuarially sound.', "So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education, we'd spend more money on housing, we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has.", 'But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget, and that would be my intention.']
dialogue: It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education, we'd spend more money on housing, we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget, and that would be my intention.
snippet_sentences: ['Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly, which uh - is of course his right, but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.']
snippet: Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly, which uh - is of course his right, but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

dialogue_sentences: ['He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours.', "Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers?", "I don't think we should have that kind of a program."]
dialogue: He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program.
snippet_sentences: ["Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way.", "Well, what he is saying there in effect, we're going to have inflation.", "We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board."]
snippet: Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well, what he is saying there in effect, we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board.

dialogue_sentences: ['There is one issue that stands out above all the rest, one in which every American is concerned, regardless of what group he may be a member and regardless of where he may live.', 'And that issue, very simply stated, is this: how can we keep the peace - keep it without surrender?', 'How can we extend freedom - extend it without war?']
dialogue: There is one issue that stands out above all the rest, one in which every American is concerned, regardless of what group he may be a member and regardless of where he may live. And that issue, very simply stated, is this: how can we keep the peace - keep it without surrender? How can we extend freedom - extend it without war?
snippet_sentences: ['Now in determining how we deal with this issue, we must find the answer to a very important but simple question: who threatens the peace?', 'Who threatens freedom in the world?']
snippet: Now in determining how we deal with this issue, we must find the answer to a very important but simple question: who threatens the peace? Who threatens freedom in the world?

dialogue_sentences: ['I also have had the opportunity of knowing and meeting other Communist leaders in the world.', 'I believe there are certain principles we must find in dealing with him and his colleagues - principles, if followed, that will keep the peace and that also can extend freedom.', 'First, we have to learn from the past, because we cannot afford to make the mistakes of the past.']
dialogue: I also have had the opportunity of knowing and meeting other Communist leaders in the world. I believe there are certain principles we must find in dealing with him and his colleagues - principles, if followed, that will keep the peace and that also can extend freedom. First, we have to learn from the past, because we cannot afford to make the mistakes of the past.
snippet_sentences: ['In the seven years before this Administration came into power in Washington, we found that six hundred million people went behind the Iron Curtain.']
snippet: In the seven years before this Administration came into power in Washington, we found that six hundred million people went behind the Iron Curtain.

dialogue_sentences: ['What are they?', 'Again we turn to the past.', 'Firmness but no belligerence, and by no belligerence I mean that we do not answer insult by insult.']
dialogue: What are they? Again we turn to the past. Firmness but no belligerence, and by no belligerence I mean that we do not answer insult by insult.
snippet_sentences: ['When you are proud and confident of your strength, you do not get down to the level of Mr. Khrushchev and his colleagues.']
snippet: When you are proud and confident of your strength, you do not get down to the level of Mr. Khrushchev and his colleagues.

dialogue_sentences: ['It can and will grow even more in the next four.', "And the reason that it must grow even more is because we have things to do at home and also because we're in a race for survival - a race in which it isn't enough to be ahead; it isn't enough simply to be complacent.", 'We have to move ahead in order to stay ahead.']
dialogue: It can and will grow even more in the next four. And the reason that it must grow even more is because we have things to do at home and also because we're in a race for survival - a race in which it isn't enough to be ahead; it isn't enough simply to be complacent. We have to move ahead in order to stay ahead.
snippet_sentences: ['And that is why, in this field, I have made recommendations which I am confident will move the American economy ahead - move it firmly and soundly so that there will never be a time when the Soviet Union will be able to challenge our superiority in this field.']
snippet: And that is why, in this field, I have made recommendations which I am confident will move the American economy ahead - move it firmly and soundly so that there will never be a time when the Soviet Union will be able to challenge our superiority in this field.

dialogue_sentences: ["And that is: not just to keep freedom for ourselves but to extend it to all the world, to extend it to all the world because that is America's destiny.", 'To extend it to all the world because the Communist aim is not to hold their own but to extend Communism.', 'And you cannot fight a victory for Communism or a strategy of victory for Communism with the strategy, simply of holding the line.']
dialogue: And that is: not just to keep freedom for ourselves but to extend it to all the world, to extend it to all the world because that is America's destiny. To extend it to all the world because the Communist aim is not to hold their own but to extend Communism. And you cannot fight a victory for Communism or a strategy of victory for Communism with the strategy, simply of holding the line.
snippet_sentences: ['And so I say that we believe that our policies of military strength, of economic strength, of diplomatic firmness first will keep the peace and keep it without surrender.']
snippet: And so I say that we believe that our policies of military strength, of economic strength, of diplomatic firmness first will keep the peace and keep it without surrender.

dialogue_sentences: ['Nor is the question that all Americans want peace and security an issue in this campaign.', 'The question is: are we moving in the direction of peace and security?', 'Is our relative strength growing?']
dialogue: Nor is the question that all Americans want peace and security an issue in this campaign. The question is: are we moving in the direction of peace and security? Is our relative strength growing?
snippet_sentences: ['Is, as Mr. Nixon says, our prestige at an all-time high, as he said a week ago, and that of the Communists at an all-time low?', "I don't believe it is.", "I don't believe that our relative strength is increasing."]
snippet: Is, as Mr. Nixon says, our prestige at an all-time high, as he said a week ago, and that of the Communists at an all-time low? I don't believe it is. I don't believe that our relative strength is increasing.

dialogue_sentences: ['It encourages them to begin a war.', 'And so I say that the record shows that we know how to keep the peace, to keep it without surrender.', 'Let us move now to the future.']
dialogue: It encourages them to begin a war. And so I say that the record shows that we know how to keep the peace, to keep it without surrender. Let us move now to the future.
snippet_sentences: ['It is not enough to stand on this record because we are dealing with the most ruthless, fanatical... leaders that the world has ever seen.']
snippet: It is not enough to stand on this record because we are dealing with the most ruthless, fanatical... leaders that the world has ever seen.

dialogue_sentences: ['Our policies are very different.']
dialogue: Our policies are very different.
snippet_sentences: ["I think that Senator Kennedy's policies and recommendations for the handling of the Castro regime are probably the most dangers- dangerously irresponsible recommendations that he's made during the course of this campaign."]
snippet: I think that Senator Kennedy's policies and recommendations for the handling of the Castro regime are probably the most dangers- dangerously irresponsible recommendations that he's made during the course of this campaign.

dialogue_sentences: ['We are quarantining Mr. Castro today.', 'We are cutting off the significant items that the Cuban regime needs in order to survive.', 'By cutting off trade, by cutting off our diplomatic relations as we have, we will quarantine this regime so that the people of Cuba themselves will take care of Mr. Castro.']
dialogue: We are quarantining Mr. Castro today. We are cutting off the significant items that the Cuban regime needs in order to survive. By cutting off trade, by cutting off our diplomatic relations as we have, we will quarantine this regime so that the people of Cuba themselves will take care of Mr. Castro.
snippet_sentences: ['But for us to do what Senator Kennedy has suggested would bring results which I know he would not want, and certainly which the American people would not want.']
snippet: But for us to do what Senator Kennedy has suggested would bring results which I know he would not want, and certainly which the American people would not want.

dialogue_sentences: ['First of all, the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many, many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik.', 'Second, as far as this report is concerned, I would have no objection to having it made public.', 'Third, I would say this with regard to this report, with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we\'ve been hearing about "what about American prestige abroad": America\'s prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be.']
dialogue: First of all, the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many, many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik. Second, as far as this report is concerned, I would have no objection to having it made public. Third, I would say this with regard to this report, with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about "what about American prestige abroad": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be.
snippet_sentences: ["Now, when we have a presidential candidate, for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots, they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education, and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours, and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another, when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums, that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this, what does this do to American prestige?"]
snippet: Now, when we have a presidential candidate, for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots, they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education, and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours, and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another, when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums, that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this, what does this do to American prestige?

dialogue_sentences: ['The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space.', 'We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev, "You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we\'re ahead of you in color television" in your famous discussion in the kitchen.', 'I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust.']
dialogue: The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space. We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev, "You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television" in your famous discussion in the kitchen. I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust.
snippet_sentences: ["Secondly, I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world."]
snippet: Secondly, I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world.

dialogue_sentences: ['Well, it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it.', 'Well let me make one thing clear.', 'Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong, but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism.']
dialogue: Well, it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it. Well let me make one thing clear. Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong, but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism.
snippet_sentences: ["Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong."]
snippet: Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong.

dialogue_sentences: ['And fourth, I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago.', "Part of that is because we've stood still here at home, because we haven't met our problems in the United States, because we haven't had a moving economy.", 'Part of that, as the Gallup Polls show, is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space.']
dialogue: And fourth, I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago. Part of that is because we've stood still here at home, because we haven't met our problems in the United States, because we haven't had a moving economy. Part of that, as the Gallup Polls show, is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space.
snippet_sentences: ['Mr. George Allen, head of your Information Service, has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science.', "We're first in other areas of science but in space, which is the new science, we're not first."]
snippet: Mr. George Allen, head of your Information Service, has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science. We're first in other areas of science but in space, which is the new science, we're not first.

dialogue_sentences: ["Well, I think the president of the United States last winter indicated that before he'd go to the summit in May he did last fall, he indicated that there should be some agenda, that there should be some prior agreement.", 'He hoped that there would be uh - b- be an agreement in part in disarmament.', 'He also expressed the hope that there should be some understanding of the general situation in Berlin.']
dialogue: Well, I think the president of the United States last winter indicated that before he'd go to the summit in May he did last fall, he indicated that there should be some agenda, that there should be some prior agreement. He hoped that there would be uh - b- be an agreement in part in disarmament. He also expressed the hope that there should be some understanding of the general situation in Berlin.
snippet_sentences: ['The Soviet Union refused to agree to that, and we went to the summit and it was disastrous.']
snippet: The Soviet Union refused to agree to that, and we went to the summit and it was disastrous.

dialogue_sentences: ["Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned, I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had.", 'I would just like to s- add this one point.', "If we are going to have the initiative in the world, we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States."]
dialogue: Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned, I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had. I would just like to s- add this one point. If we are going to have the initiative in the world, we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States.
snippet_sentences: ["We have to let them know that we want to help them, not because we're simply trying to save our own skins, not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them, because we stand for freedom, because if there were no Communism in the world, we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny."]
snippet: We have to let them know that we want to help them, not because we're simply trying to save our own skins, not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them, because we stand for freedom, because if there were no Communism in the world, we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny.

dialogue_sentences: ['The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw.', "I refer to the fact that in 1958, as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands.", 'General Twining, in January, fifty-nine, described the position of the United States.']
dialogue: The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw. I refer to the fact that in 1958, as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands. General Twining, in January, fifty-nine, described the position of the United States.
snippet_sentences: ['The position of the United States has been that this build-up, in the words of the president, has been foolish.']
snippet: The position of the United States has been that this build-up, in the words of the president, has been foolish.

snippet_sentences: ['I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error.']
snippet: I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error.

snippet_sentences: ['I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error.']
snippet: I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error.

dialogue_sentences: ["I don't believe that there is anything this country cannot do.", "I don't believe there's any burden, or any responsibility, that any American would not assume to protect his country, to protect our security, to advance the cause of freedom.", 'And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that.']
dialogue: I don't believe that there is anything this country cannot do. I don't believe there's any burden, or any responsibility, that any American would not assume to protect his country, to protect our security, to advance the cause of freedom. And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that.
snippet_sentences: ['Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny.']
snippet: Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny.

dialogue_sentences: ["I don't believe there's any burden, or any responsibility, that any American would not assume to protect his country, to protect our security, to advance the cause of freedom.", 'And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that.', 'Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny.']
dialogue: I don't believe there's any burden, or any responsibility, that any American would not assume to protect his country, to protect our security, to advance the cause of freedom. And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that. Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny.
snippet_sentences: ['I believe in 1960 and sixty-one and two and three we have a rendezvous with destiny.']
snippet: I believe in 1960 and sixty-one and two and three we have a rendezvous with destiny.

dialogue_sentences: ['We talk about schools - three times as many classrooms built in the past Administration - and Eisenhower - than under the Truman Administration.', "Let's talk about civil rights.", 'More progress in the past eight years than in the whole eighty years before.']
dialogue: We talk about schools - three times as many classrooms built in the past Administration - and Eisenhower - than under the Truman Administration. Let's talk about civil rights. More progress in the past eight years than in the whole eighty years before.
snippet_sentences: ['He talks about the progress in the field of slum clearance and the like.']
snippet: He talks about the progress in the field of slum clearance and the like.

dialogue_sentences: ["And this means more than what we've been doing.", 'It means keeping America even stronger militarily than she is.', 'It means seeing that our economy moves forward even faster than it has.']
dialogue: And this means more than what we've been doing. It means keeping America even stronger militarily than she is. It means seeing that our economy moves forward even faster than it has.
snippet_sentences: ['It means making more progress in civil rights than we have so that we can be a splendid example for all the world to see - a democracy in action at its best.']
snippet: It means making more progress in civil rights than we have so that we can be a splendid example for all the world to see - a democracy in action at its best.

dialogue_sentences: ['I would not favor the uh - payment of uh - of a given fixed income to people unless they are not able to work.', 'But with tax incentives for the low-income groups we could build up their uh - income levels uh - above the poverty level and not uh make welfare more uh - profitable than - than work.', "I don't believe that uh that Mr. Carter's been any more specific in this case than he has been on many other instances."]
dialogue: I would not favor the uh - payment of uh - of a given fixed income to people unless they are not able to work. But with tax incentives for the low-income groups we could build up their uh - income levels uh - above the poverty level and not uh make welfare more uh - profitable than - than work. I don't believe that uh that Mr. Carter's been any more specific in this case than he has been on many other instances.
snippet_sentences: ["I notice particularly that he didn't endorse the Humphrey-Hawkins bill which he has on occasions and which is included as a part of the Democratic platform."]
snippet: I notice particularly that he didn't endorse the Humphrey-Hawkins bill which he has on occasions and which is included as a part of the Democratic platform.

dialogue_sentences: ["On the other hand, uh when you have a bill of that magnitude, with - tho- those many provisions, a president has to sit and decide if there's more good than bad.", "And from the a- analysis that I've made so far, it seems to me that that tax bill does uh - justify my signature and my approval.", 'Well, Mr. Ford is - is uh changing uh considerably his previous philosophy.']
dialogue: On the other hand, uh when you have a bill of that magnitude, with - tho- those many provisions, a president has to sit and decide if there's more good than bad. And from the a- analysis that I've made so far, it seems to me that that tax bill does uh - justify my signature and my approval. Well, Mr. Ford is - is uh changing uh considerably his previous philosophy.
snippet_sentences: ["The present tax structure is a disgrace to this country; it's just a welfare program for the rich."]
snippet: The present tax structure is a disgrace to this country; it's just a welfare program for the rich.

dialogue_sentences: ['It has - uh left out some that I have recommended, unfortunately.', "On the other hand, uh when you have a bill of that magnitude, with - tho- those many provisions, a president has to sit and decide if there's more good than bad.", "And from the a- analysis that I've made so far, it seems to me that that tax bill does uh - justify my signature and my approval."]

snippet_sentences: ['Well, Mr. Ford is - is uh changing uh considerably his previous philosophy.']

dialogue_sentences: ['And uh - with that uh - in that framework would befit the - any improvements in the programs.', 'Now this does not include uh - any uh - uh extra control over uh unnecessary spending, the weeding out of obsolete or obsolescent programs.', "Uh - we'll have uh - a safety version built in with complete reorganization of the executive branch of government which I am pledged to do."]
dialogue: And uh - with that uh - in that framework would befit the - any improvements in the programs. Now this does not include uh - any uh - uh extra control over uh unnecessary spending, the weeding out of obsolete or obsolescent programs. Uh - we'll have uh - a safety version built in with complete reorganization of the executive branch of government which I am pledged to do.
snippet_sentences: ['The present bureaucratic structure of the - of the Federal Government is a mess.']
snippet: The present bureaucratic structure of the - of the Federal Government is a mess.

dialogue_sentences: ["And if I'm elected president that's gonna be a top priority of mine to completely revise the structure of the federal government, to make it economical, efficient, purposeful and manageable for a change.", "And also, I'm going to institute zero-based budgeting which I used four years in Georgia, which uh - assesses every program every year, and eliminates those programs that are obsolete or obsolescent.", "But with these projections, we will have a balanced budget by fiscal year 1981, if I'm elected president."]
dialogue: And if I'm elected president that's gonna be a top priority of mine to completely revise the structure of the federal government, to make it economical, efficient, purposeful and manageable for a change. And also, I'm going to institute zero-based budgeting which I used four years in Georgia, which uh - assesses every program every year, and eliminates those programs that are obsolete or obsolescent. But with these projections, we will have a balanced budget by fiscal year 1981, if I'm elected president.
snippet_sentences: ['Keep my promises to the American people.']
snippet: Keep my promises to the American people.

dialogue_sentences: ['The amnesty program that I recommended in Chicago in September of 1974 would give to all draft evaders and - uh military deserters the opportunity to earn their uh - good record back.', 'We gave them ample time.', 'I am against- an across-the-board pardon of draft evaders or military deserters.']
dialogue: The amnesty program that I recommended in Chicago in September of 1974 would give to all draft evaders and - uh military deserters the opportunity to earn their uh - good record back. We gave them ample time. I am against- an across-the-board pardon of draft evaders or military deserters.
snippet_sentences: ['Now in the case of Mr. Nixon, the reason the - the pardon was given, was that, when I took office this country was in a very, very divided condition.']
snippet: Now in the case of Mr. Nixon, the reason the - the pardon was given, was that, when I took office this country was in a very, very divided condition.

dialogue_sentences: ['In every one of these instances, the Ford administration has failed, and I hope tonight that I and Mr. Ford will have a chance to discuss the reasons for those failures.', "Our country is not strong anymore; we're not respected anymore.", "We can only be strong overseas if we're strong at home; and when I became president we'll not only be strong in those areas but also in defense - a defense capability second to none."]
dialogue: In every one of these instances, the Ford administration has failed, and I hope tonight that I and Mr. Ford will have a chance to discuss the reasons for those failures. Our country is not strong anymore; we're not respected anymore. We can only be strong overseas if we're strong at home; and when I became president we'll not only be strong in those areas but also in defense - a defense capability second to none.
snippet_sentences: ["We've lost in our foreign policy, the character of the American people."]
snippet: We've lost in our foreign policy, the character of the American people.

dialogue_sentences: ["We've got to be a nation blessed with a defense capability that's efficient, tough, capable, well organized, narrowly focused - fighting capability.", 'The ability to fight, if necessary, is the best way to avoid the chance for, or the requirement to fight.', 'And the last point I wanna make is this: Mr. Ford, Mr. Kissinger have uh - continued on with the policies and failures of Richard Nixon.']
dialogue: We've got to be a nation blessed with a defense capability that's efficient, tough, capable, well organized, narrowly focused - fighting capability. The ability to fight, if necessary, is the best way to avoid the chance for, or the requirement to fight. And the last point I wanna make is this: Mr. Ford, Mr. Kissinger have uh - continued on with the policies and failures of Richard Nixon.
snippet_sentences: ["Even the Republican platform has criticized the lack of leadership in Mr. Ford and they've criticized the foreign policy of this administration.", 'This is one instance where I agree with - with the Republican platform.']
snippet: Even the Republican platform has criticized the lack of leadership in Mr. Ford and they've criticized the foreign policy of this administration. This is one instance where I agree with - with the Republican platform.

dialogue_sentences: ['I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality.', 'And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years.']
dialogue: I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality. And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years.
snippet_sentences: ["If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa, there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world."]
snippet: If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa, there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world.

dialogue_sentences: ['I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality.', 'And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years.', "If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa, there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world."]
dialogue: I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality. And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years. If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa, there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world.
snippet_sentences: ["If we had not taken our initiative, it's very, very possible that uh - the government of Rhodesia would have been overrun and that the Soviet Union and the Cubans would have dominated uh - southern Africa."]
snippet: If we had not taken our initiative, it's very, very possible that uh - the government of Rhodesia would have been overrun and that the Soviet Union and the Cubans would have dominated uh - southern Africa.

dialogue_sentences: ["Let me assure you that we made every possible overture to the People's Republic of China and through them to the Cambodian Government.", 'Every possible diplomatic means was utilized.', 'But at the same time, I had a responsibility, and so did the National Security Coun- Council, to meet the problem at hand.']
dialogue: Let me assure you that we made every possible overture to the People's Republic of China and through them to the Cambodian Government. Every possible diplomatic means was utilized. But at the same time, I had a responsibility, and so did the National Security Coun- Council, to meet the problem at hand.
snippet_sentences: ["And we handled it responsibly and I think Captain Miller's testimony to that effect is the best evidence."]
snippet: And we handled it responsibly and I think Captain Miller's testimony to that effect is the best evidence.

snippet_sentences: ['I believe that the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries because those businesses trade with Israel or because they have American Jews who are owners or directors in the company is an absolute disgrace.']
snippet: I believe that the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries because those businesses trade with Israel or because they have American Jews who are owners or directors in the company is an absolute disgrace.

dialogue_sentences: ["And I don't believe that Arab countries will pursue it when we have a strong president who will protect the integrity of our country, the commitment of our Constitution and Bill of Rights and protect people in this country who happen to be Jews.", 'It may later be Catholics; it may be - later be Baptists who are threatened by some foreign country.', 'But we ought to stand staunch.']
dialogue: And I don't believe that Arab countries will pursue it when we have a strong president who will protect the integrity of our country, the commitment of our Constitution and Bill of Rights and protect people in this country who happen to be Jews. It may later be Catholics; it may be - later be Baptists who are threatened by some foreign country. But we ought to stand staunch.
snippet_sentences: ["And I think it's a disgrace that so far Mr. Ford's administration has blocked the passage of legislation that would've revealed by law every instance of the boycott and it would've prevented the boycott from continuing."]
snippet: And I think it's a disgrace that so far Mr. Ford's administration has blocked the passage of legislation that would've revealed by law every instance of the boycott and it would've prevented the boycott from continuing.

dialogue_sentences: ['Let me restate uh - our policy.', 'As long as Vietnam, North Vietnam, does not give us a full and complete accounting of our missing in action, I will never uh - go along with the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations.']
dialogue: Let me restate uh - our policy. As long as Vietnam, North Vietnam, does not give us a full and complete accounting of our missing in action, I will never uh - go along with the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations.
snippet_sentences: ['One of the uh - most embarrassing uh - failures of the Ford administration, and one that touches specifically on human rights, is his refusal to appoint a presidential commission to go to Vietnam, to go to Laos, to go to Cambodia and try to trade for the release of information about those who are missing in action in those wars.']
snippet: One of the uh - most embarrassing uh - failures of the Ford administration, and one that touches specifically on human rights, is his refusal to appoint a presidential commission to go to Vietnam, to go to Laos, to go to Cambodia and try to trade for the release of information about those who are missing in action in those wars.

dialogue_sentences: ['The purpose of this debate and the outcome of the election will determine three basic things: Leadership, upholding the principles of our country, and proper priorities and commitments for the future.', 'This election will also determine what kind of world we leave our children.']
dialogue: The purpose of this debate and the outcome of the election will determine three basic things: Leadership, upholding the principles of our country, and proper priorities and commitments for the future. This election will also determine what kind of world we leave our children.
snippet_sentences: ['Will it be a nightmare world threatened with the proliferation of atomic bombs, not just in five major countries but dozens of smaller countries that have been permitted to develop atomic weapons because of a failure of our top leadership to stop proliferation?', "Will we have a world of hunger and - and hatred, and will we be living in an armed camp stripped of our friendship and allies hiding behind a tight defense that's been drawn in around us because we are fearful of the outside world?"]
snippet: Will it be a nightmare world threatened with the proliferation of atomic bombs, not just in five major countries but dozens of smaller countries that have been permitted to develop atomic weapons because of a failure of our top leadership to stop proliferation? Will we have a world of hunger and - and hatred, and will we be living in an armed camp stripped of our friendship and allies hiding behind a tight defense that's been drawn in around us because we are fearful of the outside world?

dialogue_sentences: ['Mr. Carter has indicated he would look with sympathy to a Communist government in NATO.', 'I think that would destroy the integrity and the strength of NATO, and I am totally opposed to it.', 'I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy.']
dialogue: Mr. Carter has indicated he would look with sympathy to a Communist government in NATO. I think that would destroy the integrity and the strength of NATO, and I am totally opposed to it. I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy.
snippet_sentences: ['That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country.']
snippet: That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country.

dialogue_sentences: ["I think it's in the best interest of the United States, and the world as a whole that the United States negotiate rather than go back to the cold-war relationship with the Soviet Union.", "I don't uh - look at the picture as bleakly as you have indicated in your question, Mr. Trewhitt.", 'I believe that the United States ha- had many successes in recent years, in recent months, as far as the Communist movement is concerned.']
dialogue: I think it's in the best interest of the United States, and the world as a whole that the United States negotiate rather than go back to the cold-war relationship with the Soviet Union. I don't uh - look at the picture as bleakly as you have indicated in your question, Mr. Trewhitt. I believe that the United States ha- had many successes in recent years, in recent months, as far as the Communist movement is concerned.
snippet_sentences: ['We have been successful in Portugal, where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal.', "It didn't happen.", 'We have a democracy in Portugal today.']
snippet: We have been successful in Portugal, where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal. It didn't happen. We have a democracy in Portugal today.

dialogue_sentences: ['As a matter of fact, Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget.', 'After he fired James Schlesinger, the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion.', 'And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon.']
dialogue: As a matter of fact, Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget. After he fired James Schlesinger, the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion. And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon.
snippet_sentences: ["Obviously, this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes, which he's trying to do tonight."]
snippet: Obviously, this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes, which he's trying to do tonight.

dialogue_sentences: ["So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country, and they don't require long experience in foreign policy.", "But my background, my experience, my knowledge of the people of this country, my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.", 'First of all, I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret, as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford.']
dialogue: So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country, and they don't require long experience in foreign policy. But my background, my experience, my knowledge of the people of this country, my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world. First of all, I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret, as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford.
snippet_sentences: ["In many instances we've made agreements, like in Vietnam, uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment."]
snippet: In many instances we've made agreements, like in Vietnam, uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment.

dialogue_sentences: ['When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense.', 'Dean Acheson, George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state.', 'But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support.']
dialogue: When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense. Dean Acheson, George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state. But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support.
snippet_sentences: ['The members of Congress, Arthur Vandenberg, Walter George, were part of the process, and before our nation made a secret agreement, or before we made a bluffing statement, we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state, but also of the Congress and the people.']
snippet: The members of Congress, Arthur Vandenberg, Walter George, were part of the process, and before our nation made a secret agreement, or before we made a bluffing statement, we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state, but also of the Congress and the people.

dialogue_sentences: ['But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support.', 'The members of Congress, Arthur Vandenberg, Walter George, were part of the process, and before our nation made a secret agreement, or before we made a bluffing statement, we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state, but also of the Congress and the people.', 'This is a responsibility of the president.']
dialogue: But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support. The members of Congress, Arthur Vandenberg, Walter George, were part of the process, and before our nation made a secret agreement, or before we made a bluffing statement, we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state, but also of the Congress and the people. This is a responsibility of the president.
snippet_sentences: ["And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state."]
snippet: And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.

dialogue_sentences: ['I believe I know what this country ought to be.', "I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do, and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future, if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily, economically, and the stature of our people, the meaning of the Constitution, in the future.", "Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs, it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process."]
dialogue: I believe I know what this country ought to be. I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do, and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future, if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily, economically, and the stature of our people, the meaning of the Constitution, in the future. Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs, it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process.
snippet_sentences: ['If we can just tap the intelligence and ability, the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people, we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed.']
snippet: If we can just tap the intelligence and ability, the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people, we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed.

dialogue_sentences: ['Our priorities ought to be first of all to meet our own military needs, secondly to meet the needs of our allies and friends, and only then should we ship military equipment to foreign countries.', 'As a matter of fact, Iran is gonna get eighty F-14s before we even meet our own Air Force orders for F-l4s.', 'And the shipment of Spruance-class destroyers to Iran are much more highly sophisticated than the Spruance-class destroyers that are present being delivered to our own Navy.']
dialogue: Our priorities ought to be first of all to meet our own military needs, secondly to meet the needs of our allies and friends, and only then should we ship military equipment to foreign countries. As a matter of fact, Iran is gonna get eighty F-14s before we even meet our own Air Force orders for F-l4s. And the shipment of Spruance-class destroyers to Iran are much more highly sophisticated than the Spruance-class destroyers that are present being delivered to our own Navy.
snippet_sentences: ['This is ridiculous and it ought to be changed.']
snippet: This is ridiculous and it ought to be changed.

dialogue_sentences: ['Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated.', 'In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion.', 'Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace.']
dialogue: Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated. In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion. Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace.
snippet_sentences: ["Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts."]
snippet: Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts.

dialogue_sentences: ["Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan.", 'And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas.', "We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence."]
dialogue: Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan. And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas. We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence.
snippet_sentences: ["And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world."]
snippet: And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world.

dialogue_sentences: ['I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air, from the sea, or from the land, uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement.', "He's been in office two years, and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement.", 'He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I, apparently.']
dialogue: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air, from the sea, or from the land, uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. He's been in office two years, and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I, apparently.
snippet_sentences: ["We've seen, in this world, a development of a tremendous threat to us."]
snippet: We've seen, in this world, a development of a tremendous threat to us.

dialogue_sentences: ['He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I, apparently.', "We've seen, in this world, a development of a tremendous threat to us.", 'As a nuclear engineer myself, I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power.']
dialogue: He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I, apparently. We've seen, in this world, a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself, I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power.
snippet_sentences: ['I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one.']
snippet: I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one.

dialogue_sentences: ["Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this.", 'We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium.', 'Mr. Ford, again, under pressure from the atomic energy lobby, has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants.']
dialogue: Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford, again, under pressure from the atomic energy lobby, has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants.
snippet_sentences: ['This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world.']
snippet: This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world.

dialogue_sentences: ['Mr. Ford, again, under pressure from the atomic energy lobby, has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants.', 'This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world.', 'We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about.']
dialogue: Mr. Ford, again, under pressure from the atomic energy lobby, has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about.
snippet_sentences: ["If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons.", 'This has got to be stopped.', 'That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.']
snippet: If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

dialogue_sentences: ['I think we got to stay that way and continue to increase our capabilities to meet any potential threat.', "But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles, as far as strength derived from the unity within our country, as far as strength derived from the people, the Congress, the secretary of state, the president, sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy, as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends, their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment, that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention, as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor, providing food, becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects, we're not strong.", "Also, we'll never be strong again overseas, unless we're strong at home."]
dialogue: I think we got to stay that way and continue to increase our capabilities to meet any potential threat. But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles, as far as strength derived from the unity within our country, as far as strength derived from the people, the Congress, the secretary of state, the president, sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy, as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends, their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment, that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention, as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor, providing food, becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects, we're not strong. Also, we'll never be strong again overseas, unless we're strong at home.
snippet_sentences: ['And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month.']
snippet: And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month.

dialogue_sentences: ["But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles, as far as strength derived from the unity within our country, as far as strength derived from the people, the Congress, the secretary of state, the president, sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy, as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends, their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment, that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention, as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor, providing food, becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects, we're not strong.", "Also, we'll never be strong again overseas, unless we're strong at home.", 'And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month.']

snippet_sentences: ["We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office."]
snippet: We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office.
